Graphical abstract This paper describes the synthesis of Ni-hierarchical Beta zeolite catalysts (denoted as Ni-MBeta) via a sol-gel incipient wetness impregnation (SIWI) method and their application in ethanol steam reforming. Various techniques including N2 adsorption–desorption (BET), the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and Scanning electron microscope (SEM) with EDX were employed to characterize the fresh and spent catalysts. The results showed that intracrystalline mesoporous structure could improve mass-transfer efficiency and decrease the deactivation rate. Furthermore, loading Ni by SIWI method could effectively control the particle size of Ni via strong interaction between metals and support, thus further promoting the homogeneous distribution of Ni to achieve large interface. The effect of the properties of Ni loading on the catalysts was also investigated. Results have shown the catalyst with 15% Ni was the optimized composition owing to its strong metal-support interaction and high nickel active surface area. The stability of ethanol steam reforming was enhanced because of hierarchical structure and the loading method of SIWI. Consequently, the Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst exhibited superior activity with respect to the reference Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst and Ni-Beta(G) catalyst. Keywords Hierarchical beta zeolite Intracrystalline mesopores Ethanol steam reforming Ni-based catalyst Sol-gel iso-volumetric impregnation method 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have been predicted to account for 80% of the world primary energy demand around 2030, rising consumption of which can lead to serious atmospheric haze. Therefore, it is urgent to develop economical and efficient processes for a sustainable energy production to replace the fossil fuels [1–3]. Hydrogen has been known as an available, non-polluting and renewable fuel. It is considered as the “green” energy succedaneum of the future. In this milieu, the production of bio-hydrogen, which is produced from renewable biomass, has been receiving increasing attention [4–6]. Major academic attention has been paid to biomass derived from chemical, namely, ethanol (EtOH), for its relatively high hydrogen content and innocuity [7] as well as its convenience for transportation [8]. Yet more significantly, it can be gained from fermentation of biomass, such as plants, agro-industrial wastes, forestry residues, and the organic fraction of municipal solid waste [9]. There are many ways to make hydrogen from ethanol, and markedly the ethanol steam reforming (ESR) [10–16] is of interest to chemical industries due to the high H2 selectivity and EtOH conversion rate [17]. In the past few years, various catalytic systems have been investigated for ESR, including both precious metals (Rh, Ru, Pd, Ir and Pt) and non-noble metals (Ni, Co) [7]. Compared with precious metals, non-noble metals especially nickel-based catalysts are well known for their relatively high activity in ESR, wide availability, excellent capability for CC and CH bond rupture and low costs [17–22]. Many studies have been conducted on ESR over various supported nickel-based catalysts such as Ni/Al2O3, Ni/(La2O3, Al2O3, YSZ, MgO, SBA-15), Ni/CexTi1-xO2, and nano-NiO/SiO2 [2,20,23–26]. Unfortunately, nickel-based catalysts generally suffer deactivation caused by sintering of active Ni species and coke deposition, which remains a major challenge for developing nickel −based catalysts [27,28]. Small-sized Ni particles can provide more surface active nickel atoms to improve the catalytic activity, even more importantly, they are conducive to effectively inhibit the carbon deposition, since Ni particles possesses a high saturation concentration of carbon and can lead to a low driving force for carbon diffusion through the nickel-based crystals [16,29]. There are two ways to obtain the small nickel particles. Firstly, the sol-gel method is used to acquire the nickel-based catalysts [30,31]. Secondly, an effective way of improving nickel dispersion and suppressing the aggregation of nickel particles is their accommodation in porous supports such as porous materials, which usually offer large surface area and multiple pores [2,4,8,20]. Furthermore, it has been reported that alumina (Al) can improve the dispensability of Ni and efficiently inhibit the nickel sintering and the carbon deposition during the steam reforming reactions [32–34]. In light of these, the advancement of materials of the highly ordered mesoporous combined with species of aluminum brings forth the new opportunities and broader prospects for the ESR. The hierarchical Beta zeolite with intracrystalline mesopore is deemed to be a robust supporting material. It has several obvious advantages as a support material: (1) Beta zeolite contains abundant microporous structure (three mutually perpendicular 12-ring channel systems) with high hydrothermal and thermal stability [35–37]. It is noteworthy that the mean diameter of microporous structure of Beta zeolite is slightly similar to that of EtOH. This channel structure will not affect the flow of ethanol molecule in the channel, meanwhile, extend the time of reaction and promote the ethanol molecule to react fully on active sites. (2) The hierarchical Beta zeolite possesses highly ordered transgranular and intragranular mesopore channels, large surface area, pore volume, and thick pore walls [38]. The diffusion challenges can be alleviated by the introduction of secondary porosity which allows facile diffusion of a mount of reactants before micropore is blocked, just like the overpass can ease the traffic pressure, the different flow rate lowered the deposition of carbon in the micropores [39]. This can significantly improve the vitality of the catalyst. (3) Specially, the hierarchical Beta zeolite which was synthesized by this work is Beta zeolite with a small amount of aluminum. A small quantity of Al is introduced to improve the dispersion of metal based on using few acid sites. Al is the main factor that makes Browsteric acid, which can lead to the production of carbon deposition. These outstanding texture properties would not only facilitate the catalyst to achieve a high dispersion of metallic particles, but also be beneficial to the transformation of ethanol and products. Based on the above analysis, Ni-hierarchical Beta zeolite catalysts were prepared by the sol-gel incipient wetness impregnation method (SIWI)in the present study, and then were tested in ethanol steam reforming (ESR). Catalytic tests were carried out in order to evaluate the effects of the sol gel method for loading Ni and the role of hierarchical structure. We also investigated the deactivation behaviors of the Beta. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of [C12H25(CH3)2N+(CH2)6N+(CH3)2C12H25][Br−]2 (C12-6-12) 2 mol of 1-bromododecane (99.9%) and 1 mol of N,N,N′,N′-tetramethyl-1,6-diaminohexane (99.9%) were dissolved in the acetonitrile (>99%). The mixture then reacted at 343 K under magnetic stirring for 24 h. After cooling to the room temperature, the product was filtered, washed with cold ethylacetate and dried in a vacuum oven at 313 K overnight. The as-obtained product was the surfactant [C12H25(CH3)2N+(CH2)6N+(CH3)2C12H25][Br−]2 (C12-6-12). 2.1.2 Synthesis of hierarchical Beta zeolites (MBeta) support The Beta zeolite with hierarchical porosity was synthesized by using the TEA+ as molecular zeolite template and adding a gemini surfactant C12-6-12 as a “porogen”. Briefly, the hydrothermal synthesis was performed by dissolving tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH), NaAlO2 and NaOH in DI water at the room temperature, and then the solid C12−6−12 were added sequentially at 50 °C. Finally, the fumed silica was added to the mixture at the room temperature. After aging for 30 h, a white gel whose composition is 1NaAlO2/60SiO2/3C12-6-12/8TEAOH/850H2O/4.8NaOH would be produced. The gel was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 393 K for 80 h. After crystallization, the zeolite product was filtered, washed with DI water, and dried at 373 K overnight. Finally, the obtained sample was calcined in a furnace under air atmosphere at 550 °C for 4 h to remove the surfactants. The as-obtained samples were named MBeta. For comparison, conventional Beta zeolite was also synthesized under the same ingredient just without adding the C12-6-12. The crystallization condition of conventional Beta was 413 K for 120 h. The as-synthesized sample was designated as Beta. 2.1.3 Preparation of Ni-MBeta catalyst and Ni-Beta catalyst 2.1.3.1 Sol gel iso-volumetric impregnation method (SIWI) Firstly, Ni(NO3)3·6H2O and citric acid were mixed together with an equal molar ratio, followed by the addition of DI water. The mixture was carried out at 60 °Cwith moderate stirring until got green and transparent solution. Then, it was added gradually to the MBeta zeolite. After aging at 60 °C for 12 h, the green and transparent jelly was acquired. The concentration of the solutions was suited to obtain Ni loadings of 5–15 wt%. After calcination at 550 °C for 2 h, the as-prepared catalysts were ground and sieved to 40–60 mesh particles for catalytic tests. The as-prepared catalysts were named as 5Ni-MBeta(G), 7Ni-MBeta(G), 10Ni-MBeta(G), 15Ni-MBeta(G) according to the loading amount of Ni. Ni-Beta catalyst was prepared by the same method with Ni-MBeta catalyst and it was named as 10Ni-Beta(G) according to the loading amount of Ni. 2.1.3.2 Iso-volumetric impregnation method (IWI) Catalysts were prepared by an iso-volumetric impregnation method (IWI) of MBeta using aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)3·6H2O. The concentration of the solutions was suited to obtain Ni loadings of 10 wt% after calcination at 550 °C for 2 h. The as-prepared catalysts were ground and sieved to 40–60 mesh particles for catalytic tests. The as-prepared catalyst was named as 10Ni-MBeta(N) according to the loading amount of Ni. 2.2 Characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected to determine the crystalline phase and ordered structure of the synthesized zeolite. The data were obtained on a Rigaku Dlmax-2500 instrument (40 KV, 100 Ma). The Cu/Kα radiation was at a scanning rate of 8°/min with the scanning range of 0.5°−100°. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (BET) were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument. Prior to the analysis, the samples were degassed at 573 K for 8 h with 0.1 g. The mesoporous structure was determined from the adsorption branch of isotherms by using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. And the cumulative pore volume curves and pore size distributions (PSD)were estimated by applying the NLDFT method to the adsorption branch of the isotherms, assuming cylindrical pore geometry. This method was also employed to determine the relative contribution of micro-mesopores to both surface area and pore volume. H2–temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on a FINETEC INSTRUMENTS (FINE SORE 3010) apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. Prior to each TPR, the samples, about 30 mg, were thermally treated under air stream at 573 K to remove water and other contaminants. TPR profiles were obtained by heating the samples under a 5% H2/Ar flow (35 mL/min) from 298 to 1173 K at a linearly programmed rate of 10 K/min. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) was measured on a scanning electron microscope (type SU-1500) with an acceleration voltage of 30 KV. 2.3 Catalytic performance test Catalytic performance tests were performed in a tubular fixed bed steel reactor at atmospheric pressure. x g of catalyst was mixed with 3 × g of quartz particles (x represents 0.1 or 0.3). Prior to each reaction, the system was out-gassed with N2 for 30 min, then the catalysts were reduced in H2/Ar at 873 K for 2 h, and then switched to the reaction temperature with N2 flow protection. N2 was used as support gas (35 mL/min) and the deionized water, alcohol fed continuously at a flow rate of z mL/min that resulted in different WHSV. The effluent gaseous products were analyzed on-line by a haixin 950 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD and a FID detector and two packed columns. TDX-01 packed column was used to separate H2 and N2, whereas CO, CH4, CO2, C2H4 were separated using a GDX-401 column. The liquid products collected in the gas–liquid separator were analyzed off-line on another gas chromatograph equipped with a Porapack Q column by manual injection. As a result of the products variation, the catalyst performance was characterized by two parameters. Y H 2 refers to the yield of hydrogen of H2 and ethanol conversion is denoted as X EtOH. They were calculated according to Eqs ((1)–(3)). (1) X EtOH = [ n EtOHr − n EtOHp n EtOHr ] · 100 % (2) Y H 2 = n H 2 p [ 6 · ( n EtOHr − n EtOHp ) ] · 100 % (3) S j = j Σ i · 100 % Methane was used as an external standard to calculate the carbon and hydrogen balance. In reactions, n EtOHr is mol number of carbon in the initial EtOH, n EtOHp is mol number of carbon in the result EtOH, j represents the species containing carbon in the products, including CH4, CO, CO2, C2H4 and CH3CHO, and i is the mol number of all products species. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of as-prepared catalysts 3.1.1 TEM image, SEM image and EDX mapping of calcined catalysts Fig. 1 shows the pore morphology of the MBeta and Beta samples visualized by SEM and TEM observations. As can be seen from Fig. 1 (A), the sample of Beta whose particle size was nearly 0.6 μm exhibited more smooth surface. But in Fig. 1 (B), the sample of MBeta exhibits layered structures, and its surfaces which are rough and amorphous are likely made up with smaller zeolite particles. Moreover, for samples of Beta, the presence of any secondary porosity is difficult to be observed [40]. Meanwhile, it is observed from TEM (Fig. 1 (C)) that mesopores well distributed throughout the zeolite particles are clearly appreciated in the micrographs. These facts confirm the effectiveness of the C12-6-12 treatment for generating a uniform intracrystalline mesopores when applied to a hierarchical Beta sample. As-obtained materials are continuous and open at the external surface of the sample, and crystal walls are partially connected with each other. The continuity of micropores is interdicted by mesoporous and the connectivity between the two different pores is improved. From Fig. 1 (C), interlacing channel structure of micro-mesoporous is similar to the structure of overpass. It will have better catalysis effect just as an overpass can ease the traffic pressure. The SEM image of 10Ni-MBeta(G)catalyst reveals that the support of MBeta displayed uniform morphology, and the EDX measurement (panels (D) in Fig. 1) suggest that there is the uniform composition of Ni nanoparticles over the MBeta. The content of Ni determined by EDX is close to the experimental value. 3.1.2 Surface area In order to investigate the influence of the textural properties, the textural properties of all samples discussed above were analyzed from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. And the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, the pore size distribution curves and textual properties are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 and Table 1 , respectively. As shown in Fig. 2, the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of the samples containing MBeta are a union of Type I and Type IV isotherms, indicating the coexistence of micropores and mesopores. For samples of Beta and 10Ni-Beta(G), there are not hysteresis loop. Furthermore, the samples 10Ni-MBeta(N) and 10Ni-MBeta(G) display type IV hysteresis loop isotherms, indicating that the mesoporous structures are largely maintained after the incorporation of nickel. Among the all samples, all micropores and mesopores have more symmetrical pore width distribution which is shown in Fig. 3 (A) and (B). And the peaks are widened and weakened simultaneously as a result of the partial blockage of the primary mesopores or micropores with increasing nickel addition. At the same time, hierarchy structure has more mesopores than Beta catalyst under the same parameters regardless of whether the metal is loaded or not. As is shown in Fig. 3, the pore size of mesopores is mainly 2–10 nm in the catalyst obtained by SIWI (10Ni-MBeta(G)), indicating the active metal distribution in the catalyst is more uniform and the particle size is smaller. The detailed data is shown in Table 1. The following conclusions can be got by analysing the data in Table 1. Firstly, the introduction of intracrystalline mesopores effectively increases SBET. The amount of mesopores increases significantly, and the inherent structure of micropores has not changed (compared with MBeta and Beta). Secondly, the incorporation of nickel has significant impacts on the physical properties of the samples. Notable decreases in BET surface area and pore volume are observed, indicating that nickel has successfully entered the pore systems. For Beta, the loaded metal is like the accumulative mesopores on the surface of micropores. So, the amount and pore volume of mesopores, increase greatly in 10Ni-Beta(G) catalyst. Meanwhile, micropores are obviously covered after loading active metal (SMicro obviously reduced) which is in agreement with the fact. For all samples containing MBeta, the Smicro and Smeso decreased distinctly, which further indicates that the Ni has gone into the channel and changed the morphology properties of support. It’s notable that compared with the Smeso in support MBeta and 10Ni-MBeta(N), the Smeso of 10Ni-MBeta(G) has not decreased significantly. To some extent, the metal particles are more uniform and smaller after the metal is loaded by SIWI. And at the same time, the metal particles can combine effectively with the original support. Thirdly, the hierarchy factor (HF) defined as (Vmicro/V total) × (Smeso/SBET), one of the most important factors to describe the hierarchical zeolite, was calculated for most of the samples and listed for comparison in Table 1, along with the data for conventional Beta zeolite which has the lowest hierarchy factor of about 0.090 because of the absence of meso-structures. The HF of the MBeta is considerably higher than Beta, meaning that MBeta has more spread hierarchical systems. After loading the metal, the HF decreases slightly, this is caused by the interaction between the metal and support. Interestingly, 10Ni-MBeta(G) has the best effect on preserving the pore channel properties (HF10Ni-MBeta(G) ≈ HFMBeta), and this effect is more beneficial to the utilization of the micro-mesopores to play a role in the catalytic process. To sum up, combined with the SEM results, 10Ni-MBeta(G) has rich intracrystalline hierarchical channel under preserving the properties of inherent structure. Meanwhile, active metals loaded by SIWI had a higher degree of dispersion and their particles were more uniform. 3.1.3 Powder XRD PXRD is used as a means of characterization to illustrate the effect of different loading method and the amount of Ni on the degree of spread and grain size of active metal. Fig. 4 shows diffraction pattern of 10% active metal Ni using two different loading methods on MBeta, of which the sample of using traditional IWI is 10Ni-MBeta(N) and the sample of using SIWI is 10Ni-MBeta(G). Fig. 4 (A) shows the diffraction pattern of catalyst after calcination for 2 h at 550 °C. Fig. 4 (B) shows the diffraction pattern after reduction at 600 °C. The presence of the high-angle (θ = 7.6°, θ = 22.4°) reflections of all samples indicates that the ordered BEA structure was maintained after loading Ni. As Fig. 4 (A) shows, the peaks at 37.3, 43.3and 62.9 are corresponding to the plane (111), (200) and (220) of the face-centered cubic structure of NiO (JCPDS 78-0643), respectively. Similar to 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst, only NiO and BEA structure could be observed over 10Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst. However, NiO diffraction peaks of the 10Ni-MBeta(G) are broader and weaker than those of the 10Ni-MBeta(N) obviously. Diffraction signal appears attenuated and wider in the catalyst of 10Ni-MBeta(G), which is indicative of the promoting effect of SIWI onto the MBeta support to form smaller crystallites of NiO. The mean crystallite sizes of NiO over 10Ni-MBeta(G) and 10Ni-MBeta(N) catalysts, which were calculated using the Scherer equation from line broadening of the (200) diffraction of NiO estimated by XRD, were ∼8.0 nm and ∼ 20.2 nm, respectively. After reduction in H2 for 2 h at 600 °C, the peaks assigned to NiO disappeared, and signals related to metal Ni could be detected, indicating that all of the NiO of 10Ni-MBeta(G) or 10Ni-MBeta(N) have been reduced into metal nickel successfully (Fig. 4 (B)). The mean size of metal nickel were about 6.7 nm and 16.7 nm for the reduced 10Ni-MBeta(G) and 10Ni-MBeta(N), respectively. Obviously, the crystallite size of NiO or Ni over the 10Ni-MBeta(G) is smaller than that over the 10Ni-MBeta(N). Therefore, the sol-gel incipient wetness impregnation method (SIWI) is favorable toward the formation of the smaller NiO/Ni particle and the dispersion of the NiO/Ni phase. This conclusion is consistent with the BET result. In conclusion, using SIWI method to load metal can effectively reduce the particle size of active metal and promote the more uniform distribution of active metal on the support surface. The XRD observations for these samples are in great agreement with their structural features characterized by N2 isotherms and pore size distribution data. 3.1.4 H2-TPR Since the size of the metal particles and the reducibility of the catalyst are strongly interrelated and influence the catalytic activity, samples were also characterized by H2-TPR and the corresponding profiles are showed in Fig. 5 . Regarding samples, quite different reduction profiles were obtained depending on the active phase. It is known that Ni2+ is reduced to Ni0 without any intermediate oxide [41]. The presence of several peaks suggests the existence of NiO species differently interact with the support. For the sample 10Ni-MBeta(N), the first peak at 367 °C is caused by the reduction of bulk NiO crystallites located on the external surface of MBeta with a weak interaction with the support, since unsupported NiO reduces at about 280 °C [42]. The second and third peaks, at about 412 °C and 532 °C, respectively, can be ascribed to NiO moderate interacting with the support. The broad peak at 635 °C is likely to be the reduction of nickel phyllosilicate or nickel hydrosilicate species [43]. While, the situation is quite different for 10Ni-MBeta(G). The profile of 10Ni-MBeta(G) contains a broad hydrogen uptake event with a maximum at 509 °C corresponding to the reduction of Ni2+in form of NiO. The fact that the uptake starts at 350 °C and extends over the rest of the temperature scale suggests that NiO particles of different size and with different degree of interaction with support are presented in 10Ni-MBeta(G). This situation may be caused by the reduction of NiO nanoparticles confined within the mesopores and thus resulting in a strong interaction with the support. There is also a broad shoulder on the high temperature side of the peak indicating the presence of the stronger interaction between the metal and support, with a maximum between 600 °C and 650 °C. It’s interesting to find that when using SIWI method simultaneously, different supports performed different reduction properties. This different channel structure had a big effect on the dispersion degree of metal and further reflects in the reduction properties of metal oxides. Fig. 7 represents the H2-TPR of different supports by using SIWI method to load 10% Ni. 10Ni-Beta(G) has four obvious reductive peaks. Its reductive temperature moves to high degree, in comparison with IWI method, which indicates that the degree of spread of NiO has been improved. But for the 10Ni-MBeta(G), there is only one wide peak and few obvious acute peaks, and its supreme peak moves to the direction of the high temperature, which indicates: (1) intracrystalline mesopores have a significant effect on the distribution of NiO and (2) NiO can combine with support closely. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the calcined supports Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts with different content of Ni were reported in Fig. 6 . Undoubtedly, the area of the three peaks increased with the loading of nickel. The reduction peaks of three catalysts shift towards higher temperature, indicating that the force between metal and support become stronger with the increase of loading amount. As is shown above, hierarchical Beta zeolite with intracrystalline mesopores was chosen as support for catalysts because of good connectivity of dual channels, larger BET area, and a small amount of exposed Al active sites, which make Ni disperse well on the surface of support and has a stronger interaction with support. Using SIWI method to load active metal can obviously improve the fine divergence of active metal and obtain minor metal particles. Because of the above mentioned reasons, active metal Ni can disperse on the surface and channel of support uniformly to obtain a kind of more efficient catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic results on ethanol steam reforming 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of Beta and MBeta catalyst To further study the effect of hierarchy on the catalysis reaction, the result of Ni-Beta and Ni-MBeta catalyst in the ESR reaction was compared under the same reaction conditions. And the stability of two catalysts was tested for 29 h. Besides screening the catalysts performance on the basis of ethanol conversion and H2 yield, product selectivity was also evaluated. Given the experimental parameters, both hydrogen and carbon dioxide were the major products for both catalysts as depicted in Fig. 7 (A, B). This could be attributed to the temperature dependent nature of ethanol steam reforming. In general, at low temperature, below 350 °C, reactions such as ethanol dehydrogenation, aldehyde decomposition and methanation were the main reactions. However, at the given temperature of 550 °C, ESR and coke formation were most effective [44]. From Fig. 7 (A), on 10Ni-Beta(G) catalyst, selectivity of valuable CH4 and CO increased slightly while that towards H2 and CO2 dropped significantly. The drop in H2 yield might be due to promotion of the following reaction (Eq. (4)), which converts H2 into CH4. Moreover, C2H2 had not be tested under given reaction conditions. (4) C 2H5OH + 2H2 → 2CH4 + H2O Because the selective trend of CO and CH4 is identical, it shows that ethanol decomposition is the main reaction method. When using the Beta catalysts, the reaction medium would not react fully and there are many side reactions, which caused catalysts’ deactivation gradually. For 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst, in the catalysis process of 29 h, the selectivity of H2 and CO2 had scarcely descended, but the selectivity of CO and CH4 had descended clearly. This shows that abundant intracrystalline mesopores have a great effect on the catalytic properties. The selectivity reduction of CO and CH4 illustrates that water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (5)) and methane decomposition (Eq. (6)) take place. This shows that the reaction is more complete and by-product can be transformed, which prolongs the use life of catalyst. (5) CO + H 2 O → CO 2 + H (6) CH 4 → 2H 2 + C As is shown in Fig. 9 (C), the absence of obvious deactivation after 29 h reaction on stream could be observed on 10Ni-MBeta(G). However, the 10Ni-Beta(G) displayed an apparent deactivation after 19 h reaction on stream. This shows that carbon deposition is easier to generate carbon gasification and the degree of spread of carbon deposition is higher with the presence of intracrystalline mesopores. These observations lead to the conclusion that the performance of the catalysts used for the ESR is strongly influenced by the morphological and structural properties of the catalysts. This illustrates that the hierarchical zeolite is a good support of catalyst in the ESR reaction. 3.2.2 Catalytic performance of Ni-MBeta catalyst with different method of adding Ni To further investigate the effect of size and degree of spread of active metal on the activity of catalyst, the obtained catalysts by different kinds of loading methods were used in the reaction of ESR. As is shown in Fig. 8 (A, B), the yield of hydrogen and conversion of ETOH of the Ni/MBeta catalysts increased with the increase of reaction temperature. However, high temperature was not good for obtaining the high yield of hydrogen. With further increasing the reaction temperature from 550 °C to 600 °C, a slight decrease of the high yield of hydrogen could be observed. Meanwhile, the experimental results were different only by changing the way of loading active metal when maintaining the same support and reaction condition. At the different reaction temperature, yield of hydrogen and conversion of ETOH by using the 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst were higher than by using the 10Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst. And evidently, 10Ni-MBeta(G) showed the better catalytic activities than 10Ni-MBeta(N), especially for the low reforming temperature. The stability of two catalysts were also examined at 550 °C, and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 8 (C). The absence of obvious deactivation after 32 h reaction on stream could be observed on 10Ni-MBeta (G) from Fig. 8 (C). At the initial 26 h, the relatively stable performance could be obtained over 10Ni-MBeta(N). While, the yield of hydrogen decreased from ∼77% to ∼63% after 32 h reaction on stream. Although, the deactivation of 10Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst was more obvious than the 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst, the ratio of deactivation had not descended sharply. This proves that intracrystalline hierarchy has its advantage in the redistribution of carbon deposition. By comparing the effect of the different ways of loading on the active Ni and supports, SIWI can make Ni particles more dispersed and smaller. Also, the interaction between metal and support become stronger. 3.2.3 Catalytic performance of Ni-MBeta (G) catalyst with different content of Ni The yield of hydrogen, conversion of ETOH and the selectivity of other products over Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst by varying the Ni loading and reaction temperature were reported in Fig. 9 . As expected, the XETOH of all the Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts increased with the reaction temperature and all the Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts were active for ESR with the complete ethanol conversion achieved at 550 °C. Furthermore, over Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts with the higher Ni loading (10 wt% and 15 wt%), ethanol conversion reached 95% at 500 °C (Fig. 9 (A)). From Fig. 9 (B), the Y H 2 of all the Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts increased with the reaction temperature similarly. As is shown in Fig. 9, at the fixed temperature, the yield of hydrogen increased with Ni loading from 5 wt% to 15 wt%. Obviously, 15 wt% was the appropriate loading of Ni. As can be seen from Fig. 9 (A,B), when the reaction temperature was higher than 500 °C, both 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst and 15Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst had excellent catalytic effect in terms of ethanol conversion rate and the hydrogen yield. Therefore, they were selected for further studies in this paper. ESR activity results for 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst and 15Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst were illustrated in Fig. 9 (C-D). Major products were H2, CO, CO2, CH4 and C2H2 for all the catalysts in the study. Hydrogen and C1 products were the main reaction products, which were in agreement with the equilibrium calculation [16], showing the high CC and CH cleavage ability of Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts. It can be clearly seen that 15Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst exhibited higher selectivity of CO2, as well as lower other selectivity of by-product than the 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst. From the analysis of product distribution at low temperature, the selectivity to methane was approximately equal to that to carbon monoxide and their selectivity is similar to CO2 even higher than CO2 at 400 °C. This reveals that ethanol decomposition to carbon monoxide, methane, and hydrogen is the main reaction at the low temperature. The overall decomposition reaction of ethanol could be represented as follows: (7) CH3 CH 2 OH → CO + CH 4 + H 2 Additionally, the lower selectivity of carbon dioxide could be produced either by ethanol steam reforming or by water-gas shift reaction or by methane steam reforming, which could take place simultaneously in the reaction (Eqs. (8), (5) and (9)): (8) CH3 CH 2 OH + H 2 O → CO 2 + 2H 2 (9) CH 4 + 2H 2 O → CO 2 + 4H 2 As the temperature increased from 450 to 600 °C, compared with other products containing C, carbon dioxide was the main product. Especially for 15Ni-MBeta(G), the selectivity to carbon dioxide significantly increased, whereas the selectivity to carbon monoxide, methane droped rapidly. This reveals that ethanol steam reforming instead of ethanol decomposition becomes significant, and small quantities of carbon monoxide are produced by the ethanol decomposition reaction. When the reaction temperature was 500 °C, the selectivity of CH4 and CO of the10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst is far higher than it in 15Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst, which indicates that the efficiency of catalysis of the latter is far higher than the former. Besides, in terms of the reaction conditions, except for 600 °C, the 10Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst always produced C2H2, a kind of by-product easier to produce carbon deposition, which indicates the presence of dehydration of ethanol. (Eq. (10)). (10) CH3 CH 2 OH → C 2 H 2 + H 2 O With respect to the deactivation of catalyst, 15% Ni is the optimal choice. From Fig. 9 (D), at 550 °C, the selectivity of methane and CO reached their minimum and will not decreased when raising the temperature constantly. In order to get a balance between the products distribution and energy consumption, 550 °C is adopted as the appropriate reaction temperature. 3.2.4 Time-on-stream activity of the Ni-MBeta catalyst In general, the ethanol steam reforming is considered as a severe reaction under harsh conditions and significant deactivation has been reported regardless of the metal and utilized support [45]. Therefore, catalyst stability is one of the key issues in the development of efficient catalysts for H2 production via steam reforming of ethanol. To further investigate the promotional effect of intracrystalline mesopores, stability tests have been performed to study the long-term catalytic performance of the catalysts. The stability of the catalyst was tested by determining its ESR activity over a longer period of time at the optimum temperature of 550 °C. A 27 h time-on-stream activity was measured in terms of conversion of ethanol and the selectivity of hydrogen as is shown in Fig. 10 . The catalyst was found to be quite stable as there is scarcely any drop in activity in 27 h. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts 3.3.1 Powder XRD The XRD patterns of the spent catalysts were exhibited in Fig. 11 , and these diffractograms had been compared with the database of the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD). After a 32 h time-on-stream test, the presence of the high-angle (θ=7.6°, θ=22.4°) reflections indicates that the ordered BEA structure is retained after ESR over the both used 10%Ni-MBeta(G) and 10%Ni-MBeta(N) catalysts. This fully illustrates that the framework is not destroyed and it has better hydrothermal stability, which is fit for ESR very well. In addition, there is the peak relevant to Ni species which was visible from the spectra over the both used catalysts, suggesting that this kind of catalyst has better anti-coking ability, and Ni particles sinter at higher temperature. For the spent 10%Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst, the strong signals related to graphic carbon (ICDD 26–1076) were detected. As for the used 10%Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst, except for the graphic carbon, the signals due to the NiCx (ICDD 45-0975)species appeared. It could be concluded that carbon nanofibers with regular graphite structure were the primary coke over the used 10%Ni-MBeta(N), while the formation of the NiCx species over 10%Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst was likely owing to the reaction of active Ni with amorphous carbon. Furthermore, nickel carbide is unstable and not easy to decompose into metallic as well as graphite form of nickel at high (>500 °C) temperature. Thus, this is why 10%Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst had a higher catalytic life than 10%Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst. 3.3.2 SEM images and EDX mapping of calcined catalysts Fig. 12 shows the SEM micrographs used catalyst (15%Ni-MBeta(G)) for different time. After reaction for 16 h, there was no filamentous carbon deposition. As is known to us all, filamentous carbon is easier to form in the catalyst, in which Ni is used as active metal, and it is the important carbon to make catalyst deactivation. This illustrates that hierarchical structure and SIWI method loading active metal have a big effect on the catalysis. On one hand, abundant channel diversity makes the reaction more completely, and makes it hard to accumulate for carbon deposition. On the other hand, highly dispersed and small grained active metal make it hard for carbon deposition to accumulate on the surface of metal and make active metal embedded to lead to catalyst deactivation. Fig. 12 (B) shows the presence of coke over the supporting structure, evidencing the in particular the presence of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) during ESR reaction for hydrogen production. This confirms that main coking mechanism is the formation of CNTs. It is interesting that obtained CNT morphology is neat as if it is trimmed, which illustrates that the surface is uniform in the forming process of carbon deposition. It further proves the preceding result: hierarchical structure can makes the reaction more completely and influence distribution of carbon deposition and enhance the interaction between dispersed active metal and carrier. 3.4 Mechanism of ESR reaction in MBeta A number of overpasses seem to be constructed when the irregular intracrystalline mesoporous channel is introduced into the micropores. The irregular mesoporous not only improve the mass transfer capacity of catalyst but also change the flow velocity and directions of medium, which lead to a new reaction mechanism. The scheme 1 . illustrates the flow mechanism of reactants and products in catalyst. Both reactants and products are called reaction medium in the following expression. As is shown in the Scheme 1, the flow speed and directions of the medium in two types of channels are increasingly changing. The speed in micropores is faster than it in the mesopores, which causes the whirlpool in the juncture. The whirlpool leads to reactants and intermediates contacting with active metal to make the reaction more completely. Because of the good connectivity of two types of channel structures, the reaction balance can be established constantly, which make it hard for carbon deposition to accumulate in the micropores. This special channel structure is different from the single mesopores (like SBA-15) or mechanically mixed meso-micropores. As can be shown in the SEM (Fig. 12), after 27 h, the distribution of carbon deposition is uniform. They form neat and trimmed lawn-like inactive carbon CNT, and not forming disordered fibred carbon. Thus, the experimental results are different from the two above-mentioned supports. Although the catalyst also face the inactivation problem, its advantage of channel structure is irreplaceable. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have assessed a series of Ni-MBeta catalysts by a sol-gel iso-volumetric impregnation method to load metal and evaluated their performances in ethanol steam reforming. All the catalysts exhibited excellent CC and CH cleavage ability and activity in ESR. 15% Ni loading was found to be optimum. Its products mainly consisted of hydrogen and C1 compounds. On one hand, compared with Ni-Beta, hierarchical Beta zeolites (Ni-MBeta) with highly interconnected mesopores and micropores of uniform orientation can be an effective way to control molecular traffic for improving catalytic and separation performance. The presence of intracrystalline mesoporous makes the well-dispersed nickel particles confined in the mesoporous channels and changes the flow speed and orbit of medium in the reaction system. The Ni-MBeta catalysts possessed homogeneous Ni distribution, and the increased Ni interface obviously enhanced their catalytic performances. On the other hand, loading Ni by sol-gel iso-volumetric impregnation method could effectively control the particle size of Ni via strong interaction between metal and support, moreover promoting the homogeneous distribution of Ni to achieve large interface proved by H2-TPR, PXRD, and BET Characterizations. In a word, the Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst with optimized Ni content exhibited the highest activity in ESR, owing to its highest nickel active surface area and more efficient overpass-like channel structure. Experimental results show that the 15Ni-MBeta(G) catalysts exhibited efficient and stable hydrogen production via ESR for 29 h on stream. coredata.dc:description: This paper describes the synthesis of Ni-hierarchical Beta zeolite catalysts (denoted as Ni-MBeta) via a sol-gel incipient wetness impregnation (SIWI) method and their application in ethanol steam reforming. Various techniques including N2 adsorption–desorption (BET), the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and Scanning electron microscope (SEM) with EDX were employed to characterize the fresh and spent catalysts. The results showed that intracrystalline mesoporous structure could improve mass-transfer efficiency and decrease the deactivation rate. Furthermore, loading Ni by SIWI method could effectively control the particle size of Ni via strong interaction between metals and support, thus further promoting the homogeneous distribution of Ni to achieve large interface. The effect of the properties of Ni loading on the catalysts was also investigated. Results have shown the catalyst with 15% Ni was the optimized composition owing to its strong metal-support interaction and high nickel active surface area. The stability of ethanol steam reforming was enhanced because of hierarchical structure and the loading method of SIWI. Consequently, the Ni-MBeta(G) catalyst exhibited superior activity with respect to the reference Ni-MBeta(N) catalyst and Ni-Beta(G) catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-hierarchical Beta zeolite catalysts were applied to ethanol steam reforming: Effect of sol gel method on loading Ni and the role of hierarchical structure
